title: 106_s542
content: The "New Millennium Classrooms Act" extends the age of eligible computers for donation to schools from 2 to 3 years and allows reacquired computers to be eligible for donation. These amendments apply to contributions made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 45D. CREDIT FOR COMPUTER DONATIONS TO SCHOOLS under Subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for tax credits for donating computers to schools. The school computer donation credit under section 38 allows for a tax credit equal to 30% of qualified educational contributions made by the taxpayer. The percentage increases to 50% for contributions to schools in designated zones or Indian reservations. Certain rules apply, and the section expires after 3 years from the enactment of the New Millennium Classrooms Act. The New Millennium Classrooms Act allows for a school computer donation credit under section 38, providing a tax credit for qualified educational contributions. The credit percentage varies based on the type of school and expires 3 years after the Act's enactment. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include the calculation of the credit and disallowance of deductions for the amount of credit received. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes provisions for a school computer donation credit under section 45D, with limitations on carryback of unused credits. The rules for applying this subsection are similar to those for controlled groups of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes a school computer donation credit under section 45D, effective for contributions made after the enactment of the Act.
